review.title: Diversification-Based Learning in Computing and Optimization
review.abstract: Diversification-Based Learning (DBL) derives from a collection of principles and methods introduced in the field of metaheuristics that have broad applications in computing and optimization. We show that the DBL framework goes significantly beyond that of the more recent Opposition-based learning (OBL) framework introduced in Tizhoosh (2005), which has become the focus of numerous research initiatives in machine learning and metaheuristic optimization. We unify and extend earlier proposals in metaheuristic search (Glover, 1997, Glover and Laguna, 1997) to give a collection of approaches that are more flexible and comprehensive than OBL for creating intensification and diversification strategies in metaheuristic search. We also describe potential applications of DBL to various subfields of machine learning and optimization.

sections.text: Diversification-based learning (DBL) is derived from a collection of principles and methods introduced in the field of metaheuristics that have broad applications in informatics and optimization. We show that the DBL framework goes well beyond the morerecent opposition-based learning (OBL) framework introduced in Tizhoosh (2005), which has become the focus of numerous research initiatives in the field of machine learning and metaheuristics optimization. We unify and expand previous proposals in the field of metaheuristic search (Glover, 1997, Glover and Laguna, 1997) to offer a collection of approaches that are more flexible and comprehensive than OBL to develop intensification and diversification strategies in metaheuristic search. We also describe potential applications of DBL in various areas of machine learning and optimization. Keywords: learn-based optimization; diversification strategies; metaheuristic search.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Oppositional Learning (OBL) has become a source of numerous initiatives in the field of machine learning in artificial intelligence and related initiatives to improve metaheuristic search algorithms in optimization. Since its introduction in Tizhoosh (2005), a flood of proposals and studies have emerged to use the underlying ideas in a variety of contexts. (See, for example, the surveys by Al-Qunaieer et al, 2010, Ergezer and Sikder, 2011, Xu et al., 2014a.) An earlier framework introduced in the field of metaheuristic search (Glover, 1997; Glover and Laguna, 1997) provides a basis that summarizes many of the OBL proposals and provides a basis for further improvements. Based on this foundation, we are introducing Diversification-based Learning (DBL), which produces a collection of new strategies currently available in the OBL field.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions
sections.text: The concept of "opposition," which leads to the definitions of an opposite solution introduced in the framework of oppositional learning (OBL), can be substantially expanded by referring to earlier notions of diversification arising in the field of metaheuristic search. The resulting Diversification-based Learning System (DBL) is not only more flexible than OBL, but overcomes limitations in the OBL definitions of an opposite solution. The DBL perspective broadens the concept of opposition further by referring it not only to a single solution as the opposing partner of a given solution, but to an "opposite collection" of solutions as achieved by a diversification generator. These alternative notions lead to a model that allows the concept of opposition to operate within the context of feasibility that is missing in the OBL framework, except by the device of simply rejecting an opposing solution, as the distance from a point x to a cluster boundary can be defined as the scope of diversification we can take in the OBL framework.
